newsitem.title: USA: Enron Oil says Q2 net hurt by property sales.
newsitem.headline: Enron Oil says Q2 net hurt by property sales.

text.p: Enron Oil & Gas Co said Monday its second-quarter net income, discretionary cash flow, and net operating revenues were lower than second-quarter 1996 primarily due to lower gains and proceeds from property sales and other marketing net income.

Enron Oil, a U.S. oil and gas company which is majority owned by Enron Corp, reported second quarter net income of $0.16 per share, or $24.6 million, against net income of $0.30 per share, or $47.6 million in the same period a year earlier.
Discretionary cash flow was $123.9 million in the quarter, down from $176.5 million in the year ago quarter.
Enron Oil said it is on schedule to meet its 1997 targeted volume growth.

"We are very pleased with the results of our program in North America during the first half of this year and excited about our prospects as we enter the second half," said Enron Oil chairman and chief executive Forrest Hoglund. "We are excited about our 1997 drilling success complemented with tactical acquisitions, primarily in South Texas.
"These increases demonstrate (Enron Oil) is on schedule to meet its 1997 targeted volume growth."
The company said total North America equivalent production increased over nine percent in the first half of the year compared to a year ago.
Total North America wellhead natural gas delivered volumes averaged 781 million cubic feet per day, up 12 percent from the second quarter of 1996.
North America wellhead crude oil and condensate volumes increased 24 percent to an average 13.6 thousand barrels per day.
